para.paratext: The fruit of a warrantless search is subject to evidentiary exclusion at trial unless it falls under one of the exceptions to the warrant requirement. These exceptions include, but are not limited to the following: a stop and frisk of a person; searches incident to arrest; inventory searches; automobile searches deemed necessary due to exigent circumstances or following hot pursuit by an officer; routine security searches conducted in airports, public buildings or entertainment venues; or searches conducted because contraband is visible in plain view or in an open field.[1]

Warrantless searches of a person are most common. Under state and federal law, a person may be stopped, briefly detained, and questioned by authorities if there is articulable suspicion to do so.[2] An officer who has a justifiable belief that a person may be armed and dangerous may conduct a warrantless “frisk” of the person.[3] The scope of the “frisk” must be “limited to an intrusion reasonably necessary to discover weapons on or about the person detained.”[4]

If an officer has probable cause to believe that a person possesses contraband, he may arrest the person and conduct a full-fledged search incident to the arrest.[5] However, a warrantless search of a backpack was held to be illegal where the backpack was first searched by a hospital security officer who called the police. The police proceeded with the search and found marijuana. The Georgia Court of Appeals reasoned that the state had failed to prove that the search was lawful because the officer that searched the backpack could not articulate any reason for having searched it.[6]

An officer may check “for outstanding warrants or criminal histories on the occupants of a vehicle at a valid traffic stop” if the officer has a justifiable safety concern during the stop.[7] However, evidence obtained after a car was impounded following a traffic stop should have been excluded under a motion to suppress where the stated reason for the arrest was that the driver did not have valid insurance, but where the driver showed proof of insurance on his phone app which he had purchased only days before the stop. Because the state and city databases both showed no insurance, there was articulate suspicion for the stop, but once the driver showed that he did, in fact, have insurance, there was no probable cause to issue a citation.[8]

Compelled chemical testing of a person's blood, breath, urine, or other bodily substance for alcohol or drug intoxication is considered a search requiring consent[9] or probable cause under both the United States and Georgia Constitutions.[10] However, a blood alcohol test of a driver involved in a traffic accident resulting in serious injuries or fatalities is constitutional if the investigating officer had probable cause to believe that the driver was under the influence of alcohol or other drugs.[11]

The United States Supreme Court held in Missouri v. McNeely[12] that the natural dissipation of alcohol in a person's bloodstream does not per se constitute an exigent circumstance sufficient to justify a warrantless blood test.

Law enforcement entry into a home without a search warrant and without consent or exigent circumstances “constitutes an unjustified, forcible intrusion that violates the Fourth Amendment.”[13] In Richards v. State,[14] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that exigent circumstances justified a deputy's warrantless entry into a residence in which the deputy believed children were being exposed to hazardous chemicals associated with a methamphetamine laboratory.

However, the Court of Appeals has held that drugs found under the passenger's seat of a vehicle parked in the driveway of a home were illegally seized by police where there were no exigent circumstances existed and no consent to search was given. The court further reasoned that because the vehicle was not parked in the street or a roadway and the incriminating evidence was not plainly visible, the defendant had a reasonable expectation of privacy in a vehicle parked within the curtilage of his home.[15]

The Georgia Supreme Court held as exigent a circumstance when officers “have an objectively reasonable basis for believing that a person within a premises is in need of immediate aid … or, at the scene of a homicide, to search the area for the presence of other victims or the killer.”[16]

Police may enter and search a home without a warrant if they are hotly pursuing a suspect who is aware that he is being pursued by the police because he is more “likely to disappear or destroy evidence of his wrongdoing if the officer takes the time to get a warrant.”[17] The Georgia Court of Appeals has said, “A suspect may not defeat an arrest which has been set in motion in a public place by escaping to a private place.”[18]

An individual may consent to a warrantless search[19] and “the State must prove the consent was voluntary under the totality of the circumstances.”[20] Some factors to consider are: “the age of the accused, his education, his intelligence, the length of detention, whether the accused was advised of his constitutional rights, the prolonged nature of questioning, the use of physical punishment, and the psychological impact of all these factors on the accused.”[21] No one single factor is determinative.[22]

An individual does not have a privacy right with regards to his name, date of birth and phone number accessed by a police officer by calling 911 after finding the phone in the back seat of a cab; an therefore, no search and seizure took place under the Fourth Amendment.[23]

In State v. Rosenbaum,[24] a case of first impression, the Georgia Supreme Court adopted the Eleventh Circuit test established in U.S. v. Mitchell,[25] to determine whether a search violates the Fourth Amendment where electronic devices were obtained legally without a warrant, as a search incident to arrest, and thereafter the data from the devices were examined pursuant to a warrant issued some time later.[26] In instances such as this, the following framework should be used, considering the totality of circumstances:

[F]irst, the significance of the interference with the person's possessory interest; second, the duration of the delay; third, whether or not the person consented to the seizure; and fourth, the government's legitimate interest in holding the property as evidence.[27]

In Rosenbaum, the Court affirmed the trial court's suppression of the evidence seized from the electronic devices (computer, iPad and iPhones), reasoning that no facts presented by the prosecution warranted the lapse of 17 months between the time the items were seized and the time they were examined by the prosecution, given the defendant's possessory interest in the items.
See Goger, Daniel's Georgia Criminal Trial Practice § 4:25 (2018-2019 ed.).

Roadblocks designed to arbitrarily stop drivers are constitutional if conducted for a legitimate purpose. See Baker v. State, 252 Ga. App. 695, 556 S.E.2d 892 (2001); Giacini v. State, 281 Ga. App. 426, 636 S.E.2d 145 (2006).

Goger, Daniel's Georgia Criminal Trial Practice § 3:10 (2018-2019 ed.) (citing Jones v. State, 126 Ga. App. 841, 844, 192 S.E.2d 171, 174 (1972); State v. King, 227 Ga. App. 466, 468, 489 S.E.2d 361 (1997)).
See U.S. v. Goddard, 312 F.3d 1360 (11th Cir. 2002).
State v. Cook, 337 Ga. App. 205, 786 S.E.2d 876 (2016).
State v. Williams, 264 Ga. App. 199, 590 S.E.2d 151 (2003).
State v. Lewis, 344 Ga. App. 630, 811 S.E.2d 436 (2018).

To the extent that Georgia's implied consent statute, O.C.G.A. § 40-5-55(a), requires chemical testing of a driver involved in a traffic accident resulting in serious injuries or fatalities regardless of any determination of probable cause, it authorized unreasonable searches and seizures in violation of the State and federal Constitutions. Cooper v. State, 277 Ga. 282, 285, 587 S.E.2d 605 (2003) (overruled on other grounds by, Olevik v. State, 302 Ga. 228, 806 S.E.2d 505 (2017)).
Cooper v. State, 277 Ga. 282, 285, 587 S.E.2d 605 (2003) (overruled on other grounds by, Olevik v. State, 302 Ga. 228, 806 S.E.2d 505 (2017)); Hough v. State, 279 Ga. 711, 620 S.E.2d 380 (2005).
Missouri v. McNeely, 133 S. Ct. 1552, 185 L. Ed. 2d 696 (2013).
State v. Goodman, 290 Ga. App. 196, 660 S.E.2d 21 (2008) (quoting Leon-Velazquez v. State, 269 Ga. App. 760, 761, 605 S.E.2d 400 (2004)).

A person has a similar expectation of privacy in a motel room, and an otherwise unlawful search of a motel room cannot rest upon the consent of motel management. Stoner v. State of Cal., 376 U.S. 483, 489–490, 84 S. Ct. 889, 11 L. Ed. 2d 856 (1964).
Richards v. State, 290 Ga. App. 360, 659 S.E.2d 651 (2008).
State v. Vickers, 339 Ga. App. 272, 793 S.E.2d 167 (2016).
Teal v. State, 282 Ga. 319, 323, 647 S.E.2d 15 (2007) (internal citations omitted).
Thomas v. State, 290 Ga. App. 10, 14, 658 S.E.2d 796 (2008). See also Ahmed v. State, 322 Ga. App. 154, 744 S.E.2d 345 (2013).
Anderson v. State, 265 Ga. App. 428, 433, 594 S.E.2d 669 (2004).
Smithson v. State, 275 Ga. App. 591, 594, 621 S.E.2d 783 (2005).
Lane v. State, 287 Ga. App. 503, 651 S.E.2d 798 (2007) (quoting Martinez v. State, 239 Ga. App. 662, 663, 522 S.E.2d 53 (1999)).
The court may also consider whether the person giving consent was in a vulnerable state. State v. Stephens, 289 Ga. App. 167, 657 S.E.2d 18 (2008).
Consent cannot be the result of illegal detention. State v. Brown, 273 Ga. App. 148, 614 S.E.2d 250 (2005).
Lane v. State, 287 Ga. App. 503, 651 S.E.2d 798 (2007).
State v. Hill, 338 Ga. App. 57, 789 S.E.2d 317 (2016).
State v. Rosenbaum, 305 Ga. 442, 826 S.E.2d 18 (2019).
U.S. v. Mitchell, 565 F.3d 1347 (11th Cir. 2009).
State v. Rosenbaum, 305 Ga. 442, 826 S.E.2d 18 (2019).
U.S. v. Laist, 702 F.3d 608 (11th Cir. 2012).
